sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Lomefloxacin hydrochoride (Maxaquin(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis: 400 mg ORALLY once a day for 10 days
  • Postoperative infection, Due to transrectal prostate biopsy; Prophylaxis: 400 mg ORALLY as a single dose 1-6 hr prior to surgery
  • Postoperative infection, Due to transurethral surgery; Prophylaxis: 400 mg ORALLY as a single dose 2-6 hr prior to surgery
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (uncomplicated, caused by E. coli in females) 400 mg ORALLY once a day for 3 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (uncomplicated, caused by K. pneumoniae, P. mirabilis, S. saprophyticus) 400 mg ORALLY once a day for 10 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (complicated) 400 mg ORALLY once a day for 14 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Lomefloxacin hydrochoride (Maxaquin(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Safety and efficacy in children under 18 years of age have not been established

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal impairment: CrCl 40 mL/min and greater, no dose adjustment necessary; CrCl 11-39 mL/min, give initial dose of 400 mg then 200 mg once a day

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Lomefloxacin hydrochoride (Maxaquin(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis
  • Postoperative infection, Due to transrectal prostate biopsy; Prophylaxis
  • Postoperative infection, Due to transurethral surgery; Prophylaxis
  • Urinary tract infectious disease
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Lomefloxacin hydrochoride (Maxaquin(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Cholera
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Urethritis

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• associated with moderate-to-severe phototoxicity; avoid direct and indirect sunlight while on therapy and several days after therapy
  • known or suspected CNS disorders; may predispose to seizures or lowering seizure threshold; lomefloxacin associated with increased risk for seizures when compared to other quinolones
  • safety and efficacy have not been established for the treatment of acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis caused by S. pneumoniae; should not be used if S. pneumoniae is the suspected organism
  • safety and efficacy have not been established for the treatment of P. aeruginosa bacteremia
  • neurotoxicity; risk factors include renal failure, underlying CNS disease, and increased CNS penetration of the drug
  • peripheral neuropathy; discontinue if pain, burning, tingling, numbness and/or weakness develop
  • tendonitis/rupture of tendons; risk factors include patients over 60 years of age, renal failure, dialysis, concomitant corticosteroid therapy, and dyslipidemia

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Lomefloxacin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Phototoxicity, Can be severe
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea, Nausea
  • Neurologic:Dizziness, Headache
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Torsades de pointes
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (Severe) (rare)
  • Musculoskeletal:Traumatic or non-traumatic rupture of tendon (rare)
  • Neurologic:Peripheral neuropathy (rare), Seizure (rare)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Lomefloxacin hydrochloride is a bactericidal agent that is effective against a wide range of gram-negative and gram-positive organisms. It inhibits the transcription and replication of bacterial DNA by blocking the activity of the bacterial enzyme DNA gyrase.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration, 0.8 h to 1.4 h
  • Bioavailability: 95% to 98%

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: 10% unchanged
  • Renal: approximately 65%, 9% as metabolite
  • Dialyzable: no (hemodialysis); no (peritoneal dialysis); less than 3% removed

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• 7.75 h
  • Renal impaired patients (creatine clearance 10 mL/min to 40 mL/min): 21 h
  • Renal impaired patients (creatine clearance less than 10 mL/min): 45 h

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • take with or without food, take in the evening to reduce risk of phototoxicity
  • if given together, sucralfate should not be taken within 4 h before or 2 h after the dose
  • if given together, antacids containing aluminum or magnesium should not be taken within 4 h before or 2 h after the dose
  • if given together, didanosine buffered tablets or powder for oral solution should not be taken within 4 h before or 2 h after the dose
  • if given together, mineral supplements or multivitamins with iron or minerals should not be taken within 2 h before or 2 h after the dose

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
USES: Fluoroquinolones are bacteriocidal broad spectrum antibiotics. PHARMACOLOGY: Fluoroquinolones inhibit bacterial topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase enzymes required for DNA replication, transcription, repair and recombination. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Dizziness, drowsiness, disorientation, slurred speech, nausea and vomiting. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, and insomnia. Seizures, hallucinations, elevated liver enzymes and renal toxicity are rare. Seizures appear related to predisposing factors. Hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis and vasculitis have developed. WITHDRAWAL FROM MARKET: Grepafloxacin was withdrawn from the worldwide market in October, 1999 after reports of cardiovascular toxicity; QT prolongation had been associated with its use. Gatifloxacin was voluntarily withdrawn from the market in May 2006 due to reports of severe hypo- and hyperglycemic events.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor liver enzymes and renal function with significant overdose. Monitor fluid & electrolyte status if severe GI effects; CNS function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
Unknown. Recommended dose (adults): 300-500 mg BID; contraindicated in children.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug causes mild to moderate phototoxicity. Advise patient to avoid direct and indirect sunlight during and a few days after therapy.
  • This drug may cause diarrhea, nausea, dizziness, or headache.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of neurotoxicity.
  • Instruct patients with high risk factors (over 60 years of age, renal failure, dialysis, concomitant corticosteroid therapy, or dyslipidemia) to report signs/symptoms of tendonitis.
  • Tell patient to maintain adequate hydration to prevent renal complications.
  • Risk of phototoxicity may be reduced if dose is given in the evening, at least 12 h before exposure to daylight.
  • Instruct patients using concomitant sucralfate, magnesium- or aluminum-containing antacids, or didanosine (buffered tablets or powder) to take at least 4 h before or 2 h after lomefloxacin hydrochloride. Patients using concomitant mineral supplements or multivitamins with iron should take at least 2 h before or after lomefloxacin hydrochloride.
